message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and nature of the pain, as well as the rebound tenderness and negative psoas sign, suggest acute appendicitis. The right splanchnic nerve transmits pain from the appendix region. Somatic afferent nerve fibers are responsible for pain from the abdominal wall, not the visceral organs, so options B and C can be ruled out. The pelvic nerves are not involved in transmitting pain from the appendix region.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient's pain started in the area above his umbilicus and then moved laterally to his right lower abdomen suggests that the pain is mainly transmitted by the right splanchnic nerve. The negative psoas sign rules out other possible nerve involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, along with the location of the pain and tenderness, suggest that the most likely diagnosis is acute appendicitis. The right splanchnic nerve is responsible for carrying visceral pain from the appendix to the spinal cord. Therefore, option A is the correct answer. Somatic afferent nerve fibers carry pain signals from the skin and muscles of the abdomen, but they are not responsible for visceral pain from the appendix. The pelvic nerves do not transmit pain from the appendix either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute appendicitis, which typically causes pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. The fact that the patient has rebound tenderness but a negative psoas sign suggests that the pain is mainly transmitted by the right splanchnic nerve. Somatic afferent nerve fibers located in the right flank and the pelvic nerves are less commonly involved in appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of rebound tenderness and a negative psoas sign suggests a right lower quadrant abdominal pain, which is typical for appendicitis. The right splanchnic nerve is responsible for transmitting the pain signals from the appendix to the spinal cord. Option B is incorrect because bilateral transmission is not typical for appendicitis. Option C is incorrect because the location of the pain is not in the right flank. Option D is incorrect because pelvic nerves are not typically involved in appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain starting above the umbilicus and then moving laterally to the right lower quadrant suggests appendicitis, which is mainly supplied by the right splanchnic nerve. The negative psoas sign rules out a retrocecal appendix. The remaining options are not consistent with the location of the pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with acute appendicitis, which is mainly transmitted by the right splanchnic nerve. The negative psoas sign rules out somatic afferent nerve fibers located in the right flank. The rectal exam being normal, rules out pelvic nerves being involved. Bilateral involvement of somatic afferent nerve fibers of the abdomen is very unlikely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and tenderness suggests acute appendicitis, which is usually transmitted by the right splanchnic nerve. Somatic afferent nerve fibers of the abdomen typically transmit pain in a diffuse manner, whereas somatic afferent nerve fibers located in the right flank transmit pain associated with kidney stones. Pelvic nerves mainly transmit pain associated with urogenital organs. The negative psoas sign indicates that the retroperitoneal structure is not involved.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest that he may have acute appendicitis. Rebound tenderness is associated with inflammation of the peritoneum and is transmitted via the splanchnic nerve. Therefore, the correct answer is (A), his pain is mainly transmitted by the right splanchnic nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s pain and tenderness are located in the lower right quadrant of the abdomen, which is innervated by the right splanchnic nerve. The negative psoas sign rules out retrocecal appendicitis, which is innervated by somatic afferent nerve fibers located in the right flank. The remaining options are incorrect as they do not match the location of the patient’s pain and tenderness.
